feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Flood Watch issued July 13 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM THURSDAY MORNING THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues to be possible. * WHERE...Including the following area, Central Interior. This includes the cities of Nenana, Tanana, Manley Hot Springs, and Old

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 13 at 4:05PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water On Rivers Across The Southeast Interior This Week... Glacial rivers draining the Alaska Range such as the Upper Tanana, Chisana, and Nabesna Rivers are near bankfull and are expected to remain high into the weekend. This is due heavy showers that occurred over those areas the past 3 days.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 13 at 4:05PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: Between 1.00 and 1.50 inches of rain fell in the Western Half of Denali Park today. This could cause high water and landslides in Denali Park west of Polychrome Pass tonight.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 13 at 4:05PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Heavy Rain In Isabell Pass Tonight... Between 0.50 to 1.00 inch of rain is expected over the Eastern Alaska Range tonight. This could cause high water on streams and rivers in the Alaska Range, and more landslides in the Isabell Pass area tonight and Thursday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 13 at 9:09AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Through Tonight... Snow is expected from after midnight tonight through Wednesday night. Little accumulation is expected as the snow should melt soon after it hits the ground.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Beaufort Sea Coast; Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued July 13 at 9:09AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Through Tonight... Snow is expected through tonight. Less than one inch of accumulation is expected below 2000 feet. Above 2000 feet, between 2 and 5 inches of snow is expected, with the highest amounts above 5000 feet.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued July 14 at 1:41AM PDT until July 15 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...KING TIDES WILL CAUSE MINOR COASTAL FLOODING AT LOW LYING SPOTS DURING HIGH TIDE LATE EACH NIGHT THIS WEEK... .The highest astronomical tides of the year, commonly referred to as the King Tides, will again impact the coast and bayshore each night this week through late Thursday night and have historically resulted in the localized flooding of specific low lying areas
